turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: So, so-well, here's what I wanna know. W-what...  Am I your first big romance?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh... no, no, no, no, uh, uh. No.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Well, then, w-who was?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, well, let's see, there was Dennis, from Chippewa Falls High School.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, come on-I mean, I was still younger.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Hey, that was last year.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: He was creepy.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, I-I think you're pretty lucky I came along.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, really? Well, la-de-da!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: La-de-da. If I-if anyone had ever told me that I would be taking out a girl who used expressions like "la- de-da"...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, that's right. That you really like those New York girls.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Well, no... not just, not only.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, I'd say so. You married-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Hi. Hi, hi.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Hi. Oh, hi. Hi.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, bye. She laughs and backs up slowly toward the door.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You-you play... very well.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, yeah? So do you. Oh, God, whatta-  whatta dumb thing to say, right? I mean, you say it, "You play well," and right away... I have to say well. Oh, oh... God, Annie.  Well... oh, well... la-de-da, la-de- da, la-la.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Uh... you-you wanna lift?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, why-uh... y-y-you gotta car?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No, um... I was gonna take a cab.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, no, I have a car.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You have a car?  So...  I don't understand why... if you have a car, so then-then wh-why did you say "Do you have a car?"... like you wanted a lift?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't...  I don't... Geez, I don't know, I've... I wa- This... yeah, I got this VW out there...  What a jerk, yeah. Would you like a lift?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Sure. W-w-w-which way yuh goin'?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Me? Oh, downtown!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Down- I'm-I'm goin' uptown.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, well, I'm goin' uptown, too.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Uh, well, you just said you were going downtown.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, well, I'm, but I...

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: So sorry.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I mean, I can go uptown, too. I live uptown, but... uh, what the hell, I mean, it'd be nice having company, you know I mean, I hate driving alone.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: So, how long do you know Janet? Where do you know her from?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, I'm in her acting class.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh - you're an actress.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I do commercials, sort of...

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I, uh... well, you're not from New York, right?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, Chippewa Falls.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Right!  Where?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Wisconsin.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Uh, you're driving a-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Uh, don't worry, I'm a very-  a very good driver.  So, listen-hey, you want some gum, anyway?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No, no thanks. Hey, don't-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, where is it? I-

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No, no, no, no, you just... just watch the road. I'll get it-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: For yuh.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Okay, that's good.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I'll getcha a piece.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah... so, listen-you drive?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Do I drive? Uh, no, I gotta-I gotta problem with driving.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, you do?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah. I got, uh, I got a license but I have too much hostility.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, right.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Nice car.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You keep it nice.  Can I ask you, is this-is this a sandwich?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Huh? Oh, yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: That's okay, you... we-we can walk to the curb from here.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Don't be funny.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You want your tennis stuff?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Huh? Oh... yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You want your gear? Here you go.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, thanks. Thanks a lot. Well...

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Well, thanks, thank you. You-you're a wonderful tennis player.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You're the worst driver I've ever seen in my life... that's including any place... the worst... Europe, United... any place... Asia.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: And I love what you're wearin'.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Who? Grammy? Grammy Hall?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, my grammy.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You're jo- Whatta yuh kid- What did you do, grow up in a Norman Rockwell painting?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, I know.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Your grammy!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I know, it's pretty silly, isn't it?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Jesus, my-my grammy... n-never gave gifts, you know. She-she was too busy getting raped by Cossacks.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Well... thank you again.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, yeah, yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I'll see yuh.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Hey, well, listen... hey, you wanna come upstairs and, uh... and have a glass of wine and something? Aw, no, I mean... I mean, you don't have to, you're probably late and everything else ...

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No, no, that'll be fine. I don't mind. Sure.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You sure?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No, I got time.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Sure, I got... I got nothing, uh, nothing till my analyst's appointment.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, you see an analyst?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Y-y-yeah, just for fifteen years.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Fifteen years?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, uh, I'm gonna give him one more year and then I'm goin' to Lourdes.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Fifteen-aw, come on, you're... yeah, really?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Sylvia Plath.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: M'hm...

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Interesting poetess whose tragic suicide was misinterpreted as romantic, by the college-girl mentality.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, sorry.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Right. Well, I don't know, I mean, uh, some of her poems seem - neat, you know.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Neat?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Neat, yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Uh, I hate to tell yuh, this is nineteen seventy-five, you know that "neat" went out, I would say, at the turn of the century.  Who-who are-who are those photos on the wall?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh... oh, well, you see now now, uh, that's my dad, that's Father-and that's my... brother, Duane.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Duane?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, right, Duane-and over there is Grammy Hall, and that's Sadie.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Well, who's Sadie?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Sadie? Oh, well, Sadie...  Sadie met Grammy through, uh, through Grammy's brother George. Uh, George was real sweet, you know, he had that thing. What is that thing where you, uh, where you, uh, fall asleep in the middle of a sentence, you know-what is it? Uh...

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Uh, narcolepsy.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Narcolepsy, right, right. Right. So, anyway, so...  George, uh, went to the union, see, to get his free turkey, be-because, uh, the union always gave George this big turkey at Christmas time because he was...  shell-shocked, you know what I mean, in the First World War.  Anyway, so, so...  George is standing in line, oh, just a sec... uh, getting his free turkey, but the thing is, he falls asleep and he never wakes up. So, so...  so, he's dead ...  he's dead. Yeah. Oh, dear. Well, terrible, huh, wouldn't you say? I mean, that's pretty unfortunate.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, it's a great story, though, I mean, I... I... it really made my day. Hey, I think I should get outta here, you know, 'cause I think I'm imposing, you know...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, really? Oh, well... uh, uh, maybe, uh, maybe, we, uh...

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: ...and... uh, yeah, uh... uh, you know, I-I-I...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I mean, you don't have to, you know.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No, I know, but... but, you know, I'm all perspired and everything.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, didn't you take, uh... uh, a shower at the club?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Me? No, no, no, 'cause I never shower in a public place.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: 'Cause I don't like to get naked in front of another man, you know-it's, uh...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, I see, I see.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You know, I don't like to show my body to a man of my gender-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah. Oh, yeah. Yeah, I see. I guess-

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: 'cause, uh, you never know what's gonna happen.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Fifteen years, huh?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Fifteen years, yeah.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah. Oh, God bless!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: God bless.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, uh...  You're what Grammy Hall would call a real Jew.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, thank you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, well... you- She hates Jews. She thinks that they just make money, but let me tell yuh, I mean, she's the one yeah, is she ever. I'm tellin' yuh.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: So, did you do shoot the photographs in there or what?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, I sorta dabble around, you know.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I don't know. I mean, I guess- I guess you must be sorta late, huh?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You know, I gotta get there and begin whining soon... otherwise I- Hey... well, are you busy Friday night?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Me? Oh, uh.  No.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry, wait a minute, I have something. Well, what about Saturday night?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh... nothing. Not-no, no!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, you... you're very popular, I can see.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Gee, boy, what do you have? You have plague?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I mean, I meet a lot of... jerks, you know-

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, I meet a lotta jerks, too.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: what I mean?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: think that's, uh-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: But I'm thinking about getting some cats, you know, and then they... Oh, wait a second-oh, no, no, I mean  oh, shoot! No, Saturday night I'm gonna-  gonna sing. Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You're gonna sing? Do you sing? Well, no, it isn't  No kidding?  this is my first time. Oh, really? Where? I'd like to come.  Oh, no, no, no, no, no! No, I'm interested!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, no-I mean, I'm just a-auditioning sort of at club. I don't-

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No, so help me.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: it's my first time.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: That's okay, 'cause I know exactly what that's like. Listen-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: you're gonna like night clubs, they're really a lotta fun.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I was awful. I'm so ashamed! I can't sing.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, listen, so the audience was a tad restless.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Whatta you mean, a tad restless? Oh, my God, I mean, they hated me.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No, they didn't. You have a wonderful voice.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, I'm gonna quit!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No, I'm not gonna letcha. You have a great voice.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Really, do you think so, really?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: It's terrific.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, you know something? I never even took a lesson, either.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Hey, listen, listen.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Gimme a kiss.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, why not, because we're just gonna go home later, right?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: And-and uh, there's gonna be all that tension. You know, we never kissed before and I'll never know when to make the right move or anything. So we'll kiss now we'll get it over with and then we'll go eat. Okay?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, all right.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: And we'll digest our food better.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Okay?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: We can digest our-

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Okay. Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I'm gonna have a corned beef.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah... oh, uh, and I'm gonna have a pastrami on white bread with, uh, mayonnaise and tomatoes and lettuce.  Tsch, so, uh, your second wife left you and, uh, were you depressed about that?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Nothing that a few mega-vitamins couldn't cure.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh. And your first wife was Allison?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: My first... Yes, she was nice, but you know, uh, it was my fault. I was just... I was too crazy.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: M'm, that was so nice. That was nice.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: As Balzac said...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: H'm?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: "There goes another novel."  Jesus, you were great.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, yeah?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, I'm-I'm-I'm a wreck.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No.  You're a wreck.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Really. I mean it. I-I'll never play the piano again.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You're really nuts. I don't know, you really thought it was good? Tell me.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Good? I was-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No, that was the most fun I've ever had without laughing.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Here, you want some?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No, no, I-I-i, uh, I don't use any major hallucinogenics because I took a puff like five years ago at a party and

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I tried to take my pants off over my head...  ...my ear.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, I don't know, I don't really. I don't do it very often, you know, just sort of, er... relaxes me at first.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: M'hm.  You're not gonna believe this, but-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What? What?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Hey?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: H'm?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I-I-I'm gonna buy you these books, I think, because I-I think you should read them. You know, instead of that cat book.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's, uh...  that's pretty serious stuff there.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, 'cause I-I'm, you know, I'm, I'm obsessed with-with, uh, with death, I think. Big-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: big subject with me, yeah.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I've a very pessimistic view of life. You should know this about me if we're gonna go out, you know. I-I-I feel that life is-is divided up into the horrible and the miserable.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: M'hm.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Those are the two categories...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: M'hm.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: ...you know, they're- The-the horrible would be like, uh, I don't know, terminal cases, you know?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: M'hm.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: And blind people, crippled...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I don't-don't know how they get through life. It's amazing to me.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: M'hm.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You know, and the miserable is everyone else. That's-that's all. So- so when you go through life you should be thankful that you're miserable, because that's- You're very lucky... to be...  ...to be miserable.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: U-huh.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Look, look at that guy.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: M'hm.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: There's-there's-there's-there's Mr. When-in-the-Pink, Mr. Miami Beach, there, you know?  He's the latest! just came back from the gin-rummy farm last night. He placed third.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: M'hm. Yeah. Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Look at these guys.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, that's hilarious. They're back from Fire Island. They're... they're sort of giving it a chance-you know what I mean?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh! Italian, right?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, he's the Mafia. Linen Supply Business or Cement and Contract, you know what I mean?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No, I'm serious.  I just got my mustache wet.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, yeah?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: And there's the winner of the Truman Capote look-alike contest.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You see, like you and I...

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You are extremely sexy.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, I'm not.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Unbelievably sexy. Yes, you are. Because... you know what you are? You're-you're polymorphously perverse.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, what does-what does that mean? I don't know what that is.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Uh... uh, you're-you're exceptional in bed because you got -you get pleasure in every part of your body when I touch you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Ooooh!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You know what I mean? Like the tip o'your nose, and if I stroke your teeth or your kneecaps... you get excited.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Come on.  Yeah. You know what? You know, I like you, I really mean it. I really do like you.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You- Do you love me?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Do I love you?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: That's the key question.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I know you've only known me a short while.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I certainly... I think that's very- Yeah, yeah...  yeah. Do you love me?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I-uh, love is, uh, is too weak a word for what...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I love you.  You know I lo-ove you, I-I love you.  I-I have to invent- Of course I love you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Don't you think I do?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I dunno.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Whatta you mean? You're not gonna give up your own apartment, are you?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, bu-bu-but why?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I mean, I'm moving in with you, that's why.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, but you-you got a nice apartment.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I have a tiny apartment.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, I know it's small.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's right, and it's got bad plumbing and bugs.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: All right, granted, it has bad plumbing and bugs, but you-you say that like it's a negative thing. You know, bugs are-are-uh, entomology is a...  ...rapidly growing field.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You don't want me to live with you?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: How- I don't want you to live with me? How- Whose idea was it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Mine.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Ye-ah. Was it... It was yours actually, but, uh, I approved it immediately.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I guess you think that I talked you into something, huh?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No-what, what...? I... we live together, we sleep together, we eat together. Jesus, you don't want it to be like we're married, do yuh?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: How is it any different?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: It's different 'cause you keep your own apartment.  Because you know it's there, we don't have to go to it, we don't have to deal with it, but it's like a-a-a free-floating life raft... that we know that we're not married.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That little apartment is four hundred dollars a month, Alvy.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: That place is four hundred dollars a month?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yes, it is.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: It's-it's got bad plumbing and bugs. Jesus, I'll-My accountant will write it off as a tax deduction, I'll pay for it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You don't think I'm smart enough to be serious about.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Hey, don't be ridiculous.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Then why are you always pushing me to take those college courses like I was dumb or something?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: 'Cause adult education's a wonderful thing. You meet a lotta interesting professors. You know, it's stimulating.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Does this sound like a good course? Uh, "Modern American Poetry"? Uh, or, uh-let's see now... maybe I should, uh, take "Introduction to the Novel."

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Just don't take any course where they make you read Beowulf.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What?  Hey, listen, what-what do you think? Do you think we should, uh, go to that-that party in Southampton tonight?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No, don't be silly. What-what do we need other people for?  You know, we should-we should just turn out the lights, you know, and play hide and seek or something.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, okay. Well, listen, I'm gonna get a cigarette, okay?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, grass, right? The illusion that it will make a white woman more like Billie Holiday.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, have you ever made love high?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Me, no. You... I-I-you know, if I have grass or alcohol or anything I get unbearably wonderful. I get too, too wonderful for words. You know, I don't-I don't know why you have to, uh, get high every time we make love.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It relaxes me.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, you-you have to be artificially relaxed before we can go to bed?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, what's the difference, anyway?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Well, I'll give you a shot of sodium pentothal. You can sleep through it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, come on, look who's talking. You've been seeing a psychiatrist for fifteen years.  You should smoke some o' this. You'd be off the couch in no time.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, come, you don't need that.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No, no, no, what... You can once, you can live without it once. Come on.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, no, Alvy, please. Alvy, please.  M'mrnm.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: M'm, wait, I got a great idea.  Hang in there for a second. I got a little-little artifact. A little erotic artifact, that-that I brought up from the city, which I think, uh, is gonna be perfect.  I just... there... There's a little Old New Orleans... essence. Now-now we can go about our business here and we can even develop photographs if we want to. There, now there.  M'mmm. M'mmm. Hey, is something wrong?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Uh-uh-why?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I don't know. You- It's like you're- you're removed.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, I'm fine.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: U-huh.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I don't know, but you seem sort of distant.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Let's just do it, all right?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Is it my imagination or are you just going through the motions?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, you have my body.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, but that's not-that's no good. I want the whole thing.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I need grass and so do you.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Well, it ruins it for me if you have grass  because, you know, I'm, like, a comedian-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: M'hm.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: so if I get a laugh from a person who's high, it doesn't count. You know-'cause they're always laughin'.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Were you always funny?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Hey, what is this-an interview? We're supposed to be making love.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Alvy, you were... Alvy, you were just great, I'm not kidding. It was- You were so neat.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: C-c-coll- College audiences are so wonderful.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah. Yeah. And you know something? I think that I'm starting to get more of your references, too.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Are yuh?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Well, the twelve o'clock show is completely different than the nine.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You're so sure about it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, I'm really, uh, looking forward to tomorrow. I mean, you know, I think that it'll be really nice to meet Mother and Father.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, I know, they'll hate me immediately.  Thank you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, I don't think so. No, I don't think they're gonna hate you at all. On the contrary, I think-

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's Easter. You know, we'll have a nice dinner, we'll sit down and eat. I think they're gonna really like you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You followed me. I can't believe it!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I didn't follow you!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You followed me!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Why? 'Cause I... was walkin' along a block behind you staring at you? That's not following!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, what is your definition of following?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Following is different. I was spying.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Do you realize how paranoid you are?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Paranoid? I'm looking at you. You got your arms around another guy.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That is the worst kind of paranoia.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah-well, I didn't start out spying. I-I thought I'd surprise yuh. Pick you up after school.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah-well, you wanted to keep the relationship flexible, remember? It's your phrase.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, stop it. But you were having an affair with your college professor. That jerk that teaches that incredible crap course "Contemporary Crisis in Western Man"!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: "Existential Motifs in Russian Literature"! You're really close.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: What's the difference? It's all mental masturbation.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, well, now we're finally getting to a subject you know something about!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Hey, don't knock masturbation! It's sex with someone I love.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: We're not having an affair. He's married. He just happens to think I'm neat.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: "Neat"! There's that- What are you- twelve years old? That's one o' your Chippewa Falls expressions! "He thinks I'm neat."

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Who cares? Who cares?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Next thing you know he'll find you keen and peachy, you know? Next thing you know he's got his hand on your ass!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You've always had hostility toward David ever since I mentioned him!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: David? You call your teacher David?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's his name.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Well, listen, that's, a nice bi-it's a biblical name. Right? W-What does he call you? Bathsheba?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'm home!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, yeah? How'd it go?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, it was...  really weird. But she's a very nice woman.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: And I didn't have to lie down on the couch, Alvy, she had me sitting up. So I told her about-about the-the family and about my feelings toward men and about my relationship with my brother.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: M'm.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: And then she mentioned penis envy... Did you know about that?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Me? I'm-I'm one of the few males who suffers from that, so, so... you know.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: M'hm.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: G-go on, I'm interested.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, she said that I was very guilty about my impulses toward marriage, and-and children.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: M'hm.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: And then I remembered when I was a kid how I accidentally saw my parents making love.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Tsch. Rea- All this happened in the first hour?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: M'hm.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: That's amazing. I-I-I... I've been goin' for fifteen years, I-you know, I don't got... nothing like that in-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, I told her my dream and then I cried.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You cried? I've never once cried. Fantastic...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I whine. I-I-I sit and I whine.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: In-in... Alvy, in my dream Frank Sinatra is holding his pillow across my face and I can't breathe.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Sinatra?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, and he's strangling me...

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: and I keep, you know, it's-

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Well, well, sure... because he's a singer and you're a singer, you know, so it's perfect. So you're trying to suffocate yourself. It-it makes perfect sense. Uh, uh, that's a perfect analytic... kind of insight.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: She said, your name was Alvy Singer.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Whatta you mean? Me?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, yeah, you. Because in the dream... I break Sinatra's glasses.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Sinatra had gl- You never said Sinatra had glasses. So whatta you saying that I-I'm suffocating you?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, and God, Alvy, I did... this really terrible thing to him. Because then when he sang it was in this real high-pitched voice.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Tsch, what'd the doctor say?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, she said that I should probably come five times a week. And you know something? I don't think I mind analysis at all. The only question is, will it change my wife?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Will it change your wife?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Will it change my life?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, but you said, "Will it change my wife"!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, I didn't.  I said, "Will it change my life," Alvy.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You said, "Will it change..." Wife. Will it change...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Life. I said, "life."

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: She said, "Will it change my wife." You heard that because you were there so I'm not crazy.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: And, Alvy... and then I told her about how I didn't think you'd ever really take me seriously, because you don't think that I'm smart enough.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Adult education is such junk! The professors are so phony. How can you do it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: A bit rapidly. I don't care what you say about David, he's a perfectly fine teacher!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: David! David! I can't believe this!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: And what are you doing following me around for, anyway?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I'm following you and David, if you-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I just think we oughta call this relationship quits!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: What's- It's me, open up.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Are you okay?  What's the matter?  Are you all right? What-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: There's a spider in the bathroom.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: There's a big black spider in the bathroom.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: That's what you got me here for at three o'clock in the morning, 'cause there's a spider in the bathroom?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: My God, I mean, you know how I am about insects.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oooh.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I can't sleep with a live thing crawling around in the bathroom.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Kill it! For Go- What's wrong with you? Don't you have a can of Raid in the house?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I told you a thousand times you should always keep, uh, a lotta insect spray. You never know who's gonna crawl over.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I know, I know, and a first-aid kit and a fire extinguisher.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Jesus. All right, gimme a magazine. I- 'cause I'm a little tired.  You know, you, you joke with-about me, you make fun of me, but I'm prepared for anything. An emergency, a tidal wave, an earthquake. Hey, what is this? What? Did you go to a rock concert?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, yeah, really?  Really?  How-how'd you like it? Was it-was it, I mean, did it... was it heavy? Did it achieve total heavy-ocity? Or was it, uh...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It was just great!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, humdinger. When- Well, I got a wonderful idea. Why don'tcha get the guy who took you to the rock concert, we'll call him and he can come over and kill the spider. You know, it's a-

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: What is this? What are you, since when do you read the "National Review"? What are you turning in to?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I like to try to get all points of view.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: It's wonderful. Then why don'tcha get William F. Buckley to kill the spider?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Alvy, you're a little hostile, you know that? Not only that, you look thin and tired.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Well, I was in be- It's three o'clock in the morning. You, uh, you got me outta bed, I ran over here, I couldn't get a taxi cab. You said it was an emergency, and I didn't ge- I ran up the stairs. Hell - I was a lot more attractive when the evening began. Look, uh, tell- Whatta you- Are you going with a right-wing rock-and- roll star? Is that possible?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Would you like a glass of chocolate milk?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Hey, what am I-your son? Whatta you mean? I-I came over to --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I got the good chocolate, Alvy.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, where is the spider?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It really is lovely. It's in the bathroom.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Is he in the bathroom?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Hey, don't squish it, and after it's dead, flush it down the toilet, okay? And flush it a couple o' times.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Darling, darling, I've been killing spiders since I was thirty, okay?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh. What?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Very big spider.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Two... Yeah. Lotta, lotta trouble. There's two of 'em.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Two?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yep. I didn't think it was that big, but it's a major spider. You got a broom or something with a-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, I-I left it at your house.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: snow shovel or anything or something.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I think I left it there, I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Okay, let me have this.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, what are you doing... what are you doing with-

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Honey, there's a spider in your bathroom the size of a Buick.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Hey, what is this? You got black soap?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's for my complexion.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Whatta-whatta yuh joining a minstrel show? Geez.  Don't worry!  I did it! I killed them both. What- what's the matter? Whatta you-  whatta you sad about? You- What'd you want me to do? Capture 'em and rehabilitate 'em?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, don't go, okay? Please.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Whatta you mean, don't go? Whatta- whatta what's the matter? Whatta you expecting termites? What's the matter?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, uh, I don't know. I miss you. Tsch.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, Jesus, really?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, yeah. Oh.  Oh! Alvy?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Was there somebody in your room when I called you?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: W-w-whatta you mean?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I mean was there another- I thought I heard a voice.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, I had the radio on.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I'm sorry. I had the television set had the television-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Alvy, let's never break up again. I don't wanna be apart.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, no, no, I think we're both much too mature for something like that.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Living together hasn't been so bad, has it?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: It's all right for me, it's been terrific, you know?  Better than either one of my marriages. See, 'cause... 'cause there's just something different about you. I don't know what it is, but it's great.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You know I think that if you let me, maybe I could help you have more fun, you know? I mean, I know it's hard and... Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Alvy, what about... what if we go away this weekend, and we could-

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Tsch, why don't we get... why don't we get Rob, and the three of us'll drive into Brooklyn, you know, and we show you the old neighborhood.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Okay, okay. Okay.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: That'd be fun for yuh. Don't you think-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: -me, my God, it's a great day!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Hey, can yuh watch the road? Watch the --

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, look, look, there's that... that's that's my old house. That's where we used to live.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Holy cow!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I had a really good day, you know that? It was just a real fine way to spend my birthday.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Ah? Oh, well, your birthday's not till tomorrow, honey, I hate to tell yuh.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, but it's real close.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, but no presents till midnight.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, darn it.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Happy birthday.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What is this? Is this a... Present?  Are you kidding?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, hey, why don't yuh try it on?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Uh, yeah, uh... t-t-this is more like a present for you, yeah, but it's-

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Try it... it'll add years to our sex life.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Uh huh. Yeah. Forget it.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Here's a real present.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What... huh?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Check it out.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, yeah? What is this, anyway?  Let me see. Okay, let's... oooh, God!  Oh, you knew I wanted this...  God, it's terrific, God!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, I know. Just-just put on the watch, and-and... that thing, and we'll just...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh! My God!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You were-you were sensational. I mean, I-you know, I-I told yuh that if yuh stuck to it, you would be great, and-and, you know, I-I-you- you were sensational.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, well, we have the, I mean, they were just a terrific audience, I mean, you know, it makes it really easy for me, because I can be... huh?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Remember, we had that thing.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What thing?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Don't you remember we-we-we discussed that thing that we were-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Thing?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: yes, we had, uh...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, the thing! Oh, the thing...  ...yeah... yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: What's... you... well, what's the matter, You w-wanna go to that party?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't know, I thought it might be kind of fun, you know what I mean, it'd be nice to meet some new people.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I'm just not... you know, I don't think I could take a mellow eve- 'cause I-I don't respond well to mellow, you know what I mean, I-I have a tendency to... if I get too mellow, I-I ripen and then rot. You know, and it's-it's not good for my...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: All right, all right, you don't wanna go to the party, so uh, whatta you wanna do?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That day in Brooklyn was the last day I remember really having a great time.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Well, we never have any laughs anymore, is the problem.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I've been moody and dissatisfied.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Hardly ever. Maybe three times a week.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Constantly! I'd say three times a week. Like the other night, Alvy wanted to have sex.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: She would not sleep with me the other night, you know, it's-

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: And... I don't know... I mean, six months ago I-I woulda done it. I woulda done it, just to please him.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I mean... I tried everything, you know, I-I-I put on soft music and my- my red light bulb, and...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: But the thing is-I mean, since our discussions here, I feel I have a right to my own feelings. I think you woulda been happy because... uh, uh, I really asserted myself.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: The incredible thing about it is, I'm paying for her analysis and she's making progress and I'm getting screwed.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't know, though, I feel so guilty because Alvy is paying for it, so, you know, so I do feel guilty if I don't go to bed with him. But if I do go to bed with him, it's like I'm going against my own feelings. I don't know I-I can't win.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You know... it's getting expensive my analyst... for her analyst. She- she's making progress and I'm not making any progress. Her progress is defeating my progress.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Sometimes I think-sometimes I think I should just live with a woman.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You never wanna try anything new, Alvy.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: How can you say that? I mean,  who said I-I-I-I said that you, I and that girl from your acting class should sleep together in a threesome.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's sick!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, I know it's sick, but it's new. You know, you didn't say it couldn't be sick.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah. Come on. It'd be fun.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, I'm sure it's a lot of fun, 'cause the Incas did it, you know, and-and they-they-they were a million laughs.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Alvy, come on, for your own experience. I mean, you wanna write, why not?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: ...I'm thrilled. As you know, uh... uh, on my agent's advice I sold out, and I'm gonna do an appearance on TV.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, no, no that's not it at all. Alvy's giving an award on television. Gee, he talks like he's violating a moral issue sitting here.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: God.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Really? And what is the kick of it? Because I never...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: God, it's so clean out here.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: It's that they don't throw their garbage away. They make it into television shows.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, oh, no, I can't-I can't eat this. I'm nauseous.  If you could-if you could just give me something to get me through the next two hours, you know I-I have to go out to Burbank... and give out an award on a TV show.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well... H-h huh... Oh, good... Yes, I'll tell him.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Excuse me. I'm sorry, I'm sorry, Doctor. Uh, Alvy-Alvy, that was the show. They said everything is fine. They found a replacement, so they're going to tape without you.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I'm nauseous.  Oh, jesus, now I don't get to do the TV show?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Christ!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Nothing at all?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, this place is great.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I'm into garbage. It's my thing.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Boy, this is really a nice screening room. It's really a nice room.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, good. Okay.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I'm cool.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's wonderful. I mean, you know they just watch movies all day.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, and gradually you get old and die. You know it's important to make a little effort once in a while.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Don't you think his girl friend's beautiful?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, she's got a great-lookin' fa- A pat on the androgynous side. But it's...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Alvy, uh, let's face it. You know something, don't think our relationship is working.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Tsch, I know. A relationship, I think, is-is like a shark, you know? It has to constantly move forward or it dies.  And I think what we got on our hands  is a dead shark.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Whose "Catcher in the Rye" is this?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, let's see now... If it has my name on it, then I guess it's mine.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, it sure has... You know, you wrote your name in all my books, 'cause you knew this day was gonna come.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, uh, Alvy, you wanted to break up just as much as I do.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: There's no-no question in my mind. I think we're doing the mature thing, without any doubt.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Now, look, all the books on death and dying are yours and all the poetry books are mine.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: This "Denial of Death". You remember this?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh-

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: This is the first book that I got you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: God.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Remember that day?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Right. Geez, I feel like there's a great weight off my back. M'mmm.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Thanks, honey.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, no, no, no, no, no. I mean, you know, no, no, no, I mean, I think it's really important for us to explore new relationships and stuff like that.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, my analyst thinks this move is keen for me.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, and I-I tru- you know, I trust her, because my-my analyst recommended her.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, why should I put you through all my moods and hang-ups anyway?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Right. And you-and you know what the beauty part is?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: We can always come back together again. Because there's no-there's no problem. 'Cause... Right.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Exactly, but... exactly. Ooooh!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You know, I-I-I don't think many couples could handle this. You know, they could just break up and remain friends.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Hey, this one's mine, this button. This one, you rem-

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I guess these are all yours. Impeach, uh, Eisenhower... Impeach Nixon... Impeach Lyndon Johnson... Impeach Ronald Reagan.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You look very pretty.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, no, I just lost a little weight, that's all.  Well, you look nice.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You see, I-I've been thinking about it and I think that we should get married.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, Alvy, come on.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Why? You wanna live out here all year? It's like living in Munchkin Land.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, whatta you mean? I mean, it's perfectly fine out here. I mean, Tony's very nice and, uh, well, I meet people and I go to parties and- and we play tennis. I mean, that's... that's a very big step for me, you know?  I mean...  I'm able to enjoy people more.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: So whatta you... You're not gonna come back to New York?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What's so great about New York? I mean, it's a dying city. You read "Death in Venice."

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Hey, you didn't read "Death in Venice" till I bought it for yuh.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's right, that's right.  You only gave me books with the word "death" in the titles.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: That's right, 'cause it's an important issue.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Alvy, you're incapable of enjoying life, you know that? I mean, your life is New York City. You're just this person. You're like this island unto yourself.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I can't enjoy anything unless I... unless everybody is. I-you know, if one guy is starving someplace, that's... you know, I-I... it puts a crimp in my evening.  So wanna get married or what?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No. We're friends. I wanna remain friends.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Okay.  Check, please. Can I -can I... Can I... Can I...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You're mad, aren't you?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: No.  Yes, of course I'm mad, because you love me, I know that.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Alvy, I can't say that that's true at this point in my life. I really just can't say that that's true. I mean, you know how wonderful you are. I mean, you know... you're the reason that I got outta my room and that I was able to sing, and-and- and, you know, get more in touch with my feelings and all that crap. Anyway, look, I don't wanna- Listen, listen, listen, uh  h'h, so whatta you up to anyway, huh?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: The usual, you know. Uh, tryin' t' write. I'm workin' on a play.  Jesus. So whatta yuh saying? That you're not comin' back to New York with me?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You mean that...  I-I-I-I flew three thousand miles to see you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'm late.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Air miles, you know. I mean, you know what that does to my stomach?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: If you must know, it's a hectic time for Tony. The Grammys are tonight.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: The what?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: The Grammys. He's got a lotta records up for awards.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: You mean they give awards for that kind o' music?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I thought just earplugs.

turns.speaker: DUANE
turns.text: Alvy.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, hi, Duane, how's it goin'?

turns.speaker: DUANE
turns.text: This is my room.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, yeah?  Terrific.

turns.speaker: DUANE
turns.text: Can I confess something?

turns.speaker: DUANE
turns.text: I tell you this because, as an artist, I think you'll understand. Sometimes when I'm driving... on the road at night... I see two headlights coming toward me. Fast. I have this sudden impulse to turn the wheel quickly, head-on into the oncoming car. I can anticipate the explosion.  The sound of shattering glass. The... flames rising out of the flowing gasoline.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Right. Tsch, well, I have to-I have t-o go now, Duane, because I-I'm due back on the planet earth.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: What'd I do?

turns.speaker: TEACHER
turns.text: Step up here!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: What'd I do?

turns.speaker: TEACHER
turns.text: You should be ashamed of yourself.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Why, I was just expressing a healthy sexual curiosity.

turns.speaker: TEACHER
turns.text: Six-year-old boys don't have girls on their minds.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I did.

turns.speaker: TEACHER
turns.text: Why couldn't you have been more like Donald?  Now, there was a model boy!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Tell the folks where you are today, Donald.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Yeah, two more chairs and they got a dining-room set.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Why are you so hostile?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: 'Cause I wanna watch the Knicks on television.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Is that Paul Goodman? No. And be nice to the host because he's publishing my book. Hi, Doug! Douglas Wyatt. "A Foul-Rag-and-Bone Shop-of- the-Heart."

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: I'm so tired of spending evenings making fake insights with people who work for Dysentery.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Commentary.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Oh, really, I heard that Commentary and Dissent had merged and formed Dysentery.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: No jokes-these are friends, okay?

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Here you are. There's people out there.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Hey, you wouldn't believe this. Two minutes ago, the Knicks are ahead fourteen points, and now...  they're ahead two points.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Alvy, what is so fascinating about a group of pituitary cases trying to stuff the ball through a hoop?

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: What's fascinating is that it's physical. You know, it's one thing about intellectuals, they prove that you can be absolutely brilliant and have no idea what's going on. But on the other hand...  the body doesn't lie, as-as we now know.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Alvy, don't! You're using sex to express hostility.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: "Why-why do you always r-reduce my animal urges to psychoanalytic categories?  he said as he removed her brassiere..."

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: There are people out there from The New Yorker magazine. My God! What would they think?

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry!

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Don't get upset!

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Dammit! I was so close.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Jesus, last night it was some guy honking his car horn. I mean, the city can't close down. You know, what-whatta yuh gonna do, h-have 'em shut down the airport, too? No more flights so we can have sex?

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: I'm too tense. I need a Valium. My analyst says I should live in the country and not in New York.

turns.speaker: ALVY
turns.text: Well, I can't li- We can't have this discussion all the time. The country makes me nervous. There's... You got crickets and it-it's quiet... there's no place to walk after dinner, and... uh, there's the screens with the dead moths behind them, and... uh, yuh got the-the Manson family possibly, yuh got Dick and Terry-

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Okay, okay, my analyst just thinks I'm too tense. Where's the goddamn Valium?
